direction.raw_text: Quick cuts, seductive angles: 70 hot-air balloons rise over a vast, green corporate campus. Their mylar skins are imprinted with Outpost '98 logos; their gondolas are dressed in Outpost-colored bunting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outpost employees cheer. They're spread out over rolling lawns, amid Arabian tents and costumed Acrobats. Over the balloon-dotted sky, the graphic re-appears: "The coolest thing?"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's the beverages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUE TITLES & MUSIC) A Programmer sits in his handsome office, forested landscape out the window. The screen says: DARYL, M.I.T. '95 DARYL Gary always makes sure we've got the coolest stuff to drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of tall refrigerators: Snapples, Cokes, Fruitopias, Zaps, Jolts, Barques & Sprites are lined-up behind glass doors. "The coolest thing?"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Knowing your work means something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUE TITLES & MUSIC) A 24-year-old Korean-American Girl sits at the edge of a plashing, post-modern fountain. DIANA, STANFORD '97 DIANA (V.O.) Knowing everywhere in the world, this is the software people use.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of world capitals & remote places: Stockbrokers & Farmers, News Anchors & Students, CEO's & Eskimos boot-up Outpost '98, or log-on with Outpost Internet Traveler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over the last shot (a Ghetto Kid uses Outpost Word in the library): "The coolest thing?"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: years ago, Gary had an idea, that's all he had. And now the company's bigger than IBM.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It's the people. Which is weird.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUE TITLES & MUSIC) A Programmer sits with two colleagues, drinking lattes at the edge of Lake Washington. MITCH, BERKELEY, '98 MITCH Big companies are s'posed to be impersonal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Programmers play competitive games at an Outpost picnic; Toddlers play on computers in an Outpost Day Care Center; Geeks confer at a diagram-covered whiteboard; Employees listen/dance to the Seattle band we've been hearing, on-stage, at the Outpost '98 launch.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) There's this myth that doing a start- up is cooler. But there's no community with a start-up. No permanence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : COFFEE HOUSE/TERRACE (CONTINUE TITLES) One of Mitch's colleagues is nodding. DONNY, HARVARD, '97 DONNY It bums me out when the media say we're cultish, or whatever. Why? 'Cause we care about each other? Donny didn't mean to sound so mushy. Nobody knows where to look for a second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they laugh: "The coolest thing?"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'Love you too, bro.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll tell you what's not cool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How Gary gets this superbad rap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of magazine covers (Newsweek, Vanity Fair, WIRED) featuring Gary Boyd. They say, eg: "Who Owns Cyberspace?" On a Time cover, he's composited by the Capitol Dome: "ROBBER BARON OR VISIONARY? Outpost's Antitrust Woes"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) There's this prejudice against super- smart people. People like Gary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (early 40's) reads a statement before a Congressional Sub-Committee. His voice is pleasant but firm:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bloated Senator looks hostile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As we watch, CAMERA pulls back from the screen on which the movie is being projected. REVERSE INTO:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A kid working in his garage can create the next Outpost, the new IBM. All it takes is a great idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why nobody can have a monopoly in a business built on ideas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Over an audience of 40 or so computer students we read:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We pick out MILO CONNOR, watching keenly. He's 21: clear- eyed, alive, innocent. He sits with his best friend, TEDDY CHIN, third-generation Chinese-American.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some appreciative laughter in the auditorium. But behind Milo, LARRY LINDHOLM squirms in his seat. He whispers:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The coolest? Gary. He's like you or me. If we happened t'be insanely rich.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can we go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For me? It's Seattle!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Starting to get nauseated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: in front of Milo, twists in his seat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry gets up. Two Outpost Recruiters, REDMOND PRICE, 31 (gray suit) and DANNY BAYLOR, 29 (Outpost '98 golf shirt) note the walkout. Danny scans headshots in a Stanford Yearbook. (On-screen behind them we see Seattle: night streets wet-down & shimmering; Young People entering a club; Young People climbing Mt. Shasta.) Finding Larry's picture, Danny points out the name to Redmond, who shrugs: unconcerned.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you mind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did anybody mention the beverages?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The double-doors swing open (over them, a plate reads: THE HEWLITT-PACKARD AUDITORIUM) and Larry comes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS ALICE POULSON, a very pretty girl of 21 (more hiply dressed than the geeks) searches the hall, reading the names over the doors (NEC Communications Classroom, Toshiba Computer Lab, Mitsubishi Classroom). She spots Larry.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is it over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They still have to give 'em refreshments laced with mind-altering drugs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are a fanatic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Gonna wait outside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . - A MOMENT LATER Tilting down the neo-classical edifice, we read the name etched over the entrance: WILLIAM GATES COMPUTER SCIENCE BUILDING. We find Larry and Alice sitting on the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As we hear Larry speak, we cut back into:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (AT FIRST O.S.) Alice? You gotta make him do the start-up with Teddy and me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Make" him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thoughtfully) You know what I mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS The lights are on. Milo & Teddy stand by a table dressed in Outpost bunting, laden with refreshments & giveaways: mousepads, T-shirts, caps & books with the Outpost logo on them (a simple contour drawing of a frontier outpost). While most Students chat earnestly with Recruiters, Milo & Teddy load their plates with pizza and tortilla chips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo puts some brownies on his plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spotting a book on the table, Milo picks it up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I'm not exactly worldly, but I'm the Secretary of State next to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And they're all throwing this -- stuff at him. Stock options. Pay packages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . - CONTINUOUS LARRY I'm just screwed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry looks at her: you didn't answer my question.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (that's not true) You know what he's like. He just wants to work on stuff that's cool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't wanna move, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can paint anywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to stay here, yeah. And I kind of think he should be with Teddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Milo and Teddy discuss the book almost joyfully. (We see a page of code: utterly indecipherable.)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I mean, nobody else can follow what they're talking about half the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (under Alice) 'Could be a condition-variable in the locking code -- If it didn't seg fault, first!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . - CONTINUOUS ALICE Maybe you shouldn't push it so hard. About Outpost. No offense, you sound insane.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can't help it. I feel like they'd do anything to keep their -- ALICE Anything? That's not even credible. If he wants to go up there? To check it out? I think you should encourage him. (seeing Larry's incredulity) It's his life. But everybody's treating him like this -- valuable object. You're hurting your own case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brian, already wearing one of the Outpost caps, effuses to Redmond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Across the room, Milo (eating chips, perusing code) reaches for a napkin but unwittingly grabs some bunting. It unravels in a long TP-like streamer -- just as Danny approaches, peering at Milo's ID tag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries to sluff the paper off his hand; Danny holds out a cell phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo and Teddy look at each other: right. But Danny looks like he means it. Milo's grin fades. He takes the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny holds out two plane tickets, in 1st class folders.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's my god. I hear he actually calls recruits sometimes. Or is that an Urban Legend?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gary's running the biggest software company in the world, Brian. He's being harassed by the Justice Department, and he's got a new baby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo? I'm Danny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gary would like to speak to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo? Gary Boyd. I'm hoping you and your friend can come up here. We've made some amazing strides in digital convergence. I'd love to show them to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You would? Wow. When would we come? (he waits; he looks up) 'Think he hung up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Alice examines one of the tickets almost suspiciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry, Teddy & Brian are at the table with Alice & Milo. It's a student hang-out, with loud music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Alice predicted, Milo is pleased by Larry's remark. "Empowered." Larry smiles conspiratorially at Alice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But how does he know that's what you guys're working on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All the companies know. The faculties tell 'em. At the target schools.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In exchange for endowments. They should just drop the pretense and name the schools after 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Teddy) I can't believe you refused a ticket!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My parents're already freaked-out I'm staying here. 50 miles from Chinatown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well maybe if you told 'em how much money you'd be making -- (to Milo) You're going up there. Right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you should go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amazed) You do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, it's your life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & ALICE'S APARTMENT - MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT In a tidy, playfully decorated room, Alice stirs in bed, sees the space next to her is vacant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Milo sits at a desk, thinking, agitated, in the dim light of a PC. He looks up, sees Alice in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She picks her way through geek clutter (motherboards, code manuals, Coke cans) sits next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her: you've gotta be kidding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't deny it: she sees right through him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think I kind of lost it. I was just so thrilled to be talking to the richest, most powerful... 'Didn't know I even cared about that stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, how often do you talk to somebody who's been on the cover of Time. Three of four times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A lot of what Larry says is true. They just clone stuff, or reverse engineer it, and everybody gets stuck with their inferior version cause they -- ALICE Then you've gotta ask him about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he's really a bully, he won't cop to it, anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bully? Are we talking about Gary Boyd? Or your dad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I was a kid? And he was moving us all over the place? I spent all my time writing stuff on Outpost 1.0. I thought Gary Boyd was the greatest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he's not quite the same guy anymore. Don't get your hopes too high?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . 737 - FIRST CLASS CABIN - DAY In the cabin, everybody types on a notebook but Milo. He looks out the window expectantly: at the Seattle skyline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo comes off the plane. Danny and Redmond greet him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HIGHWAY/CAR - DAY Redmond drives his black Lexus 85 m.p.h. Danny leans forward from the backseat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo almost blushes. He makes an awkward segue.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'Couldn't convince Teddy to come?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's pretty tight with his family.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We could move 'em up here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He just likes to write code. He's bummed there's so much secrecy and competition, everybody trying to own everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who do you mean by "everybody."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So -- how far are we from the campus?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh we're not going to the campus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Beyond a rocky beach, buildings are cunningly carved into a wooded hillside. Glass walls are framed in rich wood. The main house is 28,000 sq. ft. Then there's the guest house, pool building, reception hall, library...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Redmond pulls up. A discreet Guard in a Mr. Rogers cardigan recognizes him. The gates swing open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pull up by a Lexus SUV with a baby seat. Another Man in a cardigan stands in the open front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo just sits there, eyeing the monumental residence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think they call him the "Houseman." 'Cause "guard" sounds too weird.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be nervous. The house is the weirdest thing about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's like he knows everybody expects him to be this worldly, colorful zillionaire. But he's just a guy who likes software.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Milo and the Houseman cross a long room with a lake view. We hear music by Satie. The Craftsman furniture and lamps are custom-made. A Cezanne hangs on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a Craftsman crib here, stuffed animals, another Cezanne. Even the toys seem arranged. They enter an
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ANOTHER DEN-LIKE ROOM WITH A VIEW

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS HOUSEMAN Have a seat. He won't be long. Milo sits on a bench. He tries not to look, but his childhood hero is partly visible through a glass panel in the door: Gary (in a suit and tie) has an open American face. But something goes on behind his pleasant features and self- possessed mien: his desire (or need) to solve the problem at hand is so intense it makes him appear vexed -- even vulnerable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS As Gary concentrates, two Outpost Senior Managers speak: PHIL TATE, 40 (bald); and RANDY GRIMES, 36, (gray eyes).
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We tried the big vaporware number, Gary, it's no-sale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can we buy into their IPO? Or is that a Justice Dept. problem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no public offering. The guy who wrote it joined some freakazoid cult in San Luis Obispo. 'Wrote this just to run their web site.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Gary speaks with precise hand gestures: settling the matter. Phil and Randy gather their papers, and stand. They exit, nodding at Milo as they pass. Then Gary comes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo is a little dazzled as they shake hands: such a fam- iliar face, such a big figure in his young life.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Milo? Excuse the tie. I was on TV.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...That's okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Now New Age music plays. They move back through the same room, but the Cezanne has been replaced by a Hieronymus Bosch (bodies roiling in Hell). Milo is -- puzzled.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The house knows the paintings I like, it knows my favorite music. Same for anybody else who's in the system.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - STILL MOVING As they walk, Milo watches a Cezanne "original" digitally re- configure to a Bosch, brushstrokes and all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens a glass-doored refrigerator, scans a shelf with rows of Snapples -- in alphabetical order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He selects a Kiwi-Raspberry, they walk on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Cool!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you like a Coke or something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (too shy, too nervous) Oh. No thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When we started, I just hired my smart friends. That was great. We got a little bigger, I had to hire smart strangers. Much harder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now I don't get to hire anybody. But I know you're the guy to write Skywire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They enter. An entire wall is taken-up by a Bosch triptych. As Gary crosses to the other side of the room, Milo stands by a table covered in art books -- hundreds of them (Soutine, Chinoiserie, Roy Lichtenstein...)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary heads back, carrying something spherical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Glancing down at the daunting display of books, Gary looks vaguely afflicted. He mutters:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking up now (and much more at ease) he holds up a shiny, detailed metal object: model satellite.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know a lot about art, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a rumor going around, maybe you've heard it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's more to life than computers? I'm looking into it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Once I start looking into something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've only shown this to three other people. I bought 200, we've launched 12 so far. I keep the coordinates in this room. (as Milo takes it, carefully) It's left over from SDI. Reagan's Star Wars technology? They orbit 426 miles up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Low enough to relay internet traffic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he smiles: exactly) Among other things... We know convergence is the real super-highway: all the PC's, TV's, phones, etc. linked together. Why cram it into a cable if you can use the whole sky?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning the sleek object) Skywire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Milo and Gary peer at a monitor, side-by-side. Milo sips his own Snapple now. Gary speaks his language.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo has a deer-in-the-headlights look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The content filer has t'be written into the media files so bits coming off the satellite can be read by multiplatforms. Really, omniplatforms. Including whatever new hardware emerges.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It needs a more object-oriented language. This doesn't scale, does it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd have to start practically from scratch. But this is all you'd be working on. No marketing meetings, no product seminars. We can't waste the time. Half the Valley's working on convergence. So're media conglomerates, cable companies, phone companies. 'Can't finish second, Milo. There is no second... Now what would you like to ask me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Ask you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As they walk, Milo chides himself for his reticence. Gary seems to read his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo's amazed by Gary's acuity. And his candor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have come to a stop in a windowed entryway. Milo watches Gary keenly. Gary nods. He knits his brow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know what people say, and not just the Justice Department. We clone ideas, inflict our second-rate versions on the world, we haven't done anything original since 1.0.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do I think that's fair? No. I'd put some of our apps up against anybody's. But is there some truth to it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you get to a certain age, you start wondering. About your legacy. I doubt you even remember Outpost 1.0 -- MILO I do!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleased) Yeah? I wanna feel like I did when I wrote that. But I'm 42, that's 100 in cyber-years. I look at you and see the things that got me here. (the furrows deepen) But somehow got away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A block of floodlit "tract mansions," Taco Bell palaces of the Valley's newly rich. Milo & Alice cross a vacant lot to where the lights twinkle below. Their '89 Honda Civic is parked nearby. Milo is excited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's sweet. She kisses him. He holds onto her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd hate to think that's true. But he manages a smile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If my dad'd leveled with me like that even once... The weird thing is, my fantasy he could somehow be like the old Gary? It's his fantasy, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think that's great, Milo. I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...But?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you visit the campus?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I forgot. That's why you have to help me decide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No way. You have this -- destiny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, I wouldn't have a destiny without you. My destiny would be dying at 20. From eating -- ALICE Don't bring that up. Like a different girlfriend would'd've let you die?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) You saved my life in alot of ways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not just Gary that makes you wanna go there? 'Cause it's a big place. You might not even see him again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & ALICE'S APARTMENT - DAY The Honda is loaded with luggage and boxes, some of which are tied to the roof. Milo & Alice stow a final piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they head back in, they see a Toyota park at the curb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She continues inside. He waits, watches Teddy cross the sidewalk to join him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A brown Buick parks behind Teddy's car. As they speak, a rumpled, 50ish MAN in an off-the-rack suit gets out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo grins, he high-fives Teddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They embrace. It's awkward, but it's heartfelt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When's Brian coming for the TV?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Prob'ly waiting by the phone for Outpost to call. We'll leave it for him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Give you guys some time alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You got my E-mail?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And your phone messages. You wanna do what you do, it's not a crime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that how Larry feels?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh. Not exactly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wanted to say goodbye to him...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, we got seed money for the startup! A million-five!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We rented a loft in Sunnyvale. (he gives Milo the number) You know what's the bad part? We can't talk about work anymore. We're competitors! The venture capitalists made us sign like 100 confidentiality forms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Outpost made me sign 1,000. 'Guess we'll find out what else we have to talk about. Life stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & ALICE'S APARTMENT - A MOMENT LATER Milo enters, reading Teddy's phone number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rumpled Man sits on a radiator, watching CNN on a TV, the last remaining piece of furniture. Alice enters, holding a jam jar filled water, hands Milo a business card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo reads the card: Lyle Barton, Asst. Prosecutor, DOJ, Seattle Branch Office. Milo's a little spooked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo tries to give back the card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses him. They head out. We linger. On TV a graphic says: SAN LUIS OBISPO, CA: MASS SUICIDE - LIVE. Emergency Medical Personnel roll gurneys with bodies out of a new Mediterranean mansion. Footage shows bodies (including a few children) on bunkbeds, uniformly shod in black Nikes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Guess what? They got their --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo, this is Mr. Barton from the Justice Department. (gives Barton the water) Sorry about the glass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, Milo. I'm here as a friend. Or maybe a supplicant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right... What's that mean again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beggar. We're at a disadvantage with Outpost. Our experts aren't as smart as theirs. Sometimes we can't tell which technologies pose the threat of a monopoly. We need a really smart guy to help us pick our fights. I'm taking a shot in the dark, here. I can offer you 32,000 a year, a Buick. I'm hoping you've got a feeling it's the right thing to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fiddling with the card) It's just -- I kind of feel the need to do something with my ability. Create something...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like I said: shot in the dark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you see something there that rubs you the wrong way? Do the right thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That took some fun out of -- ALICE We're not gonna let it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ingested the fatal mixture of sedatives crushed in apple sauce. According to the cult's eerily professional website, it was "time to move on..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Crane past identical, low, steel & glass buildings, amid the vast lawns & fir trees... Past a building under construction... To find Redmond's Lexus, cruising.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo looks out the window, Redmond gives the tour:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Day Care is a Michael Graves-looking building with a big cartoon-dog sculpture on its roof, ears cocked to the sky. A Teacher leads her little charges inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two Men in suits, with briefcases, (conspicuous amid the Geeks in jeans and T-shirts) enter Building #19.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car pulls into a lot full of Miatas, BMW's, Boxters.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There're 20 buildings, I mean not counting the Gyms, the Day Care, etc.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gary's put millions in there. And the people with kids? They're not hotshot geeks, they're just payroll clerks or whatever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll see alot of that: Department of Justice goons snooping around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON - THE OUTPOST LOGO THEN TILT UP TO SHOW:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The logo is of inlaid stone. Redmond & Milo walk over it. Milo carries a box with some personal effects, including a small painting. Redmond wears a photo I.D. tag.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So how'd you like the house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His Snapples were in alphabetical order.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he laughs) Well, he micro-managed the company till it got too big... (he opens the door) 'Guess he needs to micro-manage something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . 20 LOBBY - CONTINUOUS At the desk, a RECEPTIONIST looks up, stands to hang a temporary ID pass around Milo's neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo smiles. Redmond uses his magnetic swipe card on an inner door (a security cam is at every door); he holds the door open for Milo.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Milo, I'm Judith. Welcome!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They walk up a long carpeted hallway, past open offices where Geeks (mostly males under 30) sit at workstations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pass a room in which Geeks play video games. Just outside it, a chubby programmer, DESI, sips a Diet Coke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bows deep, with mock-obeisance. Milo blushes, Redmond laughs, he snags Milo's elbow. They walk again, passing a service hall with a Civil Defense sign.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody has the same office, there's no dumbass corporate hierarchy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out while you can, dude!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Desi, Milo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The guy who was at Gary's house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Best bomb shelters in America, accessible from every building. You gotta figure we're a major target, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Up the hall, a young woman (LISA) is about to go into her office. She pauses half a second, looks at Milo, goes in. She's beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they pass her office, they look in: she's already at her workstation, studiously avoiding their gaze.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Whoa. Lisa actually looked at you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every geek here's got a thing for Lisa. But that's about the biggest reaction she's had to anybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shy, changing the emphasis) She's a programmer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heavy graphical background, doing design-interface for Skywire apps. (he all but winks) You'll be working with her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got a girlfriend, remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. That's rare around here. You know how nuns' re-married to Jesus? 'Posties are married to Outpost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A handsome, modest office like all the others: workstation, whiteboard, window. They enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo puts down his box, picks up the book: The Next Highway (Gary by a highway on its cover). As we look at it:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here's your world. (pointing at the desk) Copy of Gary's book, also the audio version, narrated by Gary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The card's encoded. Tells us who came through the door and when.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In an office with a bank of monitors that play feeds from security cameras, BOB SHROT, 40, Head of Physical Security, issues Milo his swipe card. Redmond watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drags the card through a sample slot, producing an unbelievably loud, piercing EEEEEEEE. He shouts over it:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Unauthorized entries sound like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you see a tailgater, report him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tailgater?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (kills the alarm) Somebody coming in on your swipe. (gives Milo a photo ID) You see somebody wandering around without ID, it's your duty to challenge him. I don't give a shit if you're a stock-option billionaire. If you don't challenge, I'll have your butt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He seems a little -- tense.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Geeks pull his chain cause he's non- tech. Ex-cop or something. They moon cameras, or use ATM's as swipe cards. The cameras're our real security so he's a little demoralized.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As they walk, Milo watches two Hardhats roll a spool of fiber- optic cable into the building under construction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They approach a 1990 Deux Chevaux, cheap but charming.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What're they building?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #21. Way behind schedule. It's top- secret, but everybody knows it's a digital broadcast space. They see the dishes on top, the fiber optics going in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gary's not into fiber optics. He's betting everything on the satellites.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wanna survive in the software business, you cover your bets... I gotta say, this is the weirdest car anybody ever requested.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, right. Your girlfriend's an artist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . 20 CAFETERIA - DAY Blond wood, smoked glass -- a room as sleek as the Geeks who lunch here are nerdy. Milo and Redmond push trays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa's at a table, looking at Milo. When their eyes meet, she busies herself, placing the plates back on her tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa passes behind them, smiles fleetingly at Milo. At a table, Randy and Phil note the "interaction." Meantime:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I phoned her at your hotel, told her about our corporate housing options. She sounds neat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...She is. (turning away from Lisa) She is!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Might be some friction on the domestic front. You're expected you to put in ridiculous hours. People've accused us of breaking up relationships to get their undivided attention.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . 20 HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS Lisa moves swiftly up the hall. She looks up it and down it (making sure no one's looking) before ducking into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS She goes to the box on Milo's desk (his personal effects) -- starts rooting through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Redmond and Milo have eaten; Redmond stacks their plates.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your counselor'll fill you in on everything else. That's who you'll be working with almost daily.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Milo has fed the old Skywire disks into his machine. He reads a complicated screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo looks up. It's Gary. Milo is thrilled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo's smile deepens. Gary notices the small painting (by Alice) hanging on the wall. He stares at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo colors as Gary drags a second chair in front of the screen; didn't realize he was contradicting Mrs. Boyd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo smiles as Gary sits down, studies the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo can't quite get over: Gary's his counselor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Busy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! Just waiting for my counselor to come by and introduce himself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. I'm Gary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Think I should buy some originals?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Do I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somebody said I'm just another Philistine. With reproductions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's insane. You're ahead of your time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I told her. My wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Thinks I'll be less of a control freak if I have a hobby. 'Just gives me something else to obsess about...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything we can salvage from the old code before you start fresh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, might be one or two things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two awe-struck Geeks see Gary through the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's been in there like an hour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could work with a new switch. There may be a few more things hidden.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't spend too much time searching. You ever vetted somebody's old code before? (when Milo shakes his head) It's a different skill. Stay close to the surface. The best-hidden secrets are in plain sight. You know the best place to hide a leaf, right? (when Milo shakes his head) In a tree.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We're in an old (empty) Craftsman house. Through a front window, we see Alice lead Milo up a path. As they enter:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo's grinning as he takes in the house.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...The corporate condos were as romantic as they sound.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Windows give onto a garden with a small studio. Milo's still beaming, Alice is pleased. Till he says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gestures at what she hopes will be their home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pulls him back into the kiss.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know he's never been anybody's counselor before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo! What about --?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, It's great. It's great! (they start to kiss, but:) 'Think I should tell him I learned everything using 1.0? Maybe I could show him one of my early programs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .) MILO types intently in his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .) GARY sits with MILO at his desk, discussing code. Pan to the window; we see a different pair of awed Geeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .) Milo & Alice read in bed. He's reading Gary's book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .) MILO shows GARY one of his early programs, written on 1.0.: it's simple-looking, with some childish writing scrawled on it. Gary seems touched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two DOJ AGENTS depose Gary. (A video-cam records his answers.) Two Outpost LAWYERS sit next to him. One of the Agents is reading from a document:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary studies his copy of the E-mail. He looks vexed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Agent shifts in his seat. We get an idea of Gary's negotiating skill (making the other party look unreasonable, while offering nothing).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Agents confer. Gary sees Phil, looming outside the open door. One of the Agents sees him, too. He doesn't try to hide his annoyance:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "Infotek's urgent need to license Outpost Office is such that we can use it as a tool in the current negotiation." (looks up) When you wrote the word "tool," what'd you mean by it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What d'you think you meant by it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm confused. Am I supposed to speculate under oath?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since you didn't have an answer to that question, Mr. Boyd -- GARY ("confused" again) Didn't I? Have an answer? "I don't remember."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you wanna take a break, Mr. Boyd?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gary takes a manila envelope from Phil, opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary reads the page from the envelope: computer code.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your protege's moving so fast we can barely keep up with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is good. Who did it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Start-up not 50 miles from here. Kid's on Prozac.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe we should all get on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Milo stares at his screen, frustrated. Gary enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Catching himself, Gary trails off. He sits down, exhales.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary seems sincerely contrite. (He needn't be: Milo just wants to please him. Besides: Milo sees he'd like to stop obsessing about convergence, to be a "worldly zillionaire," engrossed in his hobbies; but, after all, what could be more engrossing than Skywire?)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reading the page Gary got from Phil, Milo knits his brow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How's it going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I'm going too fast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply; incredulous) Too fast? At least four companies're on the verge of workable convergence systems, Milo, they --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even when I had a hand in every aspect of the company I knew the one thing you can never control is somebody's creative process.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay. Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reaching into his pocket) Take a look at this. Slightly different approach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You did this -- overnight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're making me young again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: OFF a TV, where local news footage shows a mangled, smoking BMW, post-wreck, on a lonely nocturnal highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa watches the news report, knowingly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...A graduate of MIT, he was on the antidepressant Prozac, and had been warned not to drink and drive. (Etc.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lisa heads up the hall, carrying a CD-ROM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo's typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks. He stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This seems to jolt her. She pales a little. What a mysterious girl. But this only adds to her allure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This strikes a deep chord with Milo, all of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're looking at each other: he gets self-conscious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They sit. As she inserts the disk, he finds himself looking at her. On the screen, the frontier outpost we know as the logo appears. It's struck by a bolt from the sky. The outpost comes alive with light, music, movie-images through its windows, a ringing phone. Finally, the word SKYWIRE burns into it. It's neat, she's really good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simultaneously, they reach for the mouse. Their hands touch. They look at each other. Something happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods, manipulates the mouse. He stares at the screen strenuously, fighting the impulse to stare at Lisa.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Milo?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lisa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know my name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're famous around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (winces) I'm getting a teacher's pet rep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't worry about it. You've gotta figure most people around here were their teachers' pets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Were you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We moved around so much I barely knew my teachers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me too! Were you an Army brat or something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Something like that. Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't mean to pry. I just have this theory. Some of us who got to good at this? We were -- escaping something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did I say something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I know what you mean. I used to spend my life wishing people could be like computers. Least they make sense. Sometimes you think they've betrayed you. Like a person would. But then you see, no, you just missed a step. You can go back and make it all work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I used to wish that. All the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (re: the CD-ROM) What've you got there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Graphical interfaces. For Skywire? I'm s'posed to coordinate with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cool!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? I ran it for lots of platforms, ranging from the narrowest bandwidth to --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Sh-Show me the next one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gary's SECRETARY types as Milo enters. She smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have a seat. He's with someone, but I know he wants to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gary's face is red. The two Lawyers who sat in on his deposition are with him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary has used the phrase before, but the pretense of ingenuousness is gone; it's witheringly condescending.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Because we bundled it, the judge is threatening to enjoin the whole -- GARY I'm confused, Ted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you tell me they'd be Chapter 12 by the time they could hope to enjoin? I'm very confused, because you said they'd be ready to settle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Milo hears Gary yelling behind the closed door. It's indecipherable, but we discern an enraged "bullshit!" Milo flips through a copy of Wired, trying to ignore it. The Lawyers come out, passing swiftly, rather grimly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Go on in. (when Milo looks dubious) He's always happy to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Agitated, Gary rather compulsively lines-up the papers, pens, etc. on his desk; he barely hears the knock at the open doorframe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still distracted, he finds a page of code on his desk, gives it to Milo. Once again, Milo marvels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their eyes are locked. Gary blinks, sags into his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo just wants to get out. He studies the code to hide his discomfort. Gary watches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles. For the first time it looks forced.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Milo. What's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- you sent for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right... Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You really wrote this just today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dark, unsmiling) What're you implying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taken aback) Nothing!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everything I do is under scrutiny. The questions they ask, trying to make anything strategic look sordid. (knits his brow) I'm confused. Doesn't everybody in business try to get ahead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncomfortable) I'm sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The purpose of this company isn't to destroy our competitors any more than the purpose of living is to breath. But the software business is binary: you're a zero or a one. Being obsessive isn't a crime. It's a character trait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It scales, don't you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Definitely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A youthfully upscale place, a converted red-brick warehouse. Alice looks great. The Waiter pours wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo smiles (again it looks forced) raises his glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She just looks at him. He grows a little defensive:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A Busboy leaves a basket of rolls. Glum, preoccupied, Milo takes one without looking, brings it to his lips -- ALICE Milo! He looks at Alice, looks at the roll, blanches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He throws the roll back into the basket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the rolls: covered in seeds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles. But his heart's not in it. She hates to see him suffer. She picks up her glass.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This feels fairly grown up, I'd say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To our new life. (she's looking at him) ...What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I need to ask you. (when he says nothing) You know you can't keep anything from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He gave me some new code-fixes this morning. I said, "Did you really do this just today?" Cause I was impressed. He said "What're you implying?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the way he said it. Just the way my dad did, when he was caught in a lie. That's how you knew you were onto something ugly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (just confused) What would it mean, anyway? If he didn't write it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I'm asking myself. Does he have some genius stowed away? Why not let him write Skywire. (upset) 'Not saying it makes sense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so stupid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's your boss. He's not your -- MILO (he's nodding) I know, I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you can't deal with him on that basis, you better get a new counselor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the very idea hurts) Isn't that -- extreme?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's extreme is what that ER doctor said when he pumped your stomach. Eat another sesame seed and that's it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, if one little comment from Gary is gonna upset you this much -- MILO You're right. It's -- a working relationship. Don't know what I was expecting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon. Let's do the toast?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Milo sits alone, marking up pages of code as he eats. He doesn't notice Lisa, standing with her tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He indicates she should sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles charmingly to cover whatever she's feeling. The more enigmatic she is, the more intrigued he is.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you wanna be alone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They just pushed up the schedule on Skywire apps. How fast are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "There is no second place." Plus every time I get jammed-up, Gary has an inspiration. (looks at her, curious) Is it like that with your counselor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mine's not the CEO. He barely remembers to take a shower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right, right. But does he ever just, like, hand you code?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe once. I re-wrote it, anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he smiles) You're compulsive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmm-more like -- I have a little trouble. Trusting people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Long story. Not that interesting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . 20 QUAD - DAY Milo and Lisa walk, eat ice cream out of paper cups with Outpost logos. They laugh. We go nearer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She maintains eye contact. Her meaning is clear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo turns, sees Brian (Stanford classmate, Outpost zealot) give an envelope to a Guard at the door of #20; he trots over to Milo, who is as flustered as another guy might be having been found in bed with a girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Lisa, back to Milo, wondering why he isn't being introduced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seeing how flushed Milo is, Brian thinks he must have blundered in on something. He starts to back away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So, when you were talking about wishing people were more like computers. Was that then? Or now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then and now. (when he looks at her) But not right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just dropped off a resume. Almost got in the front door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're living here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Thought if I relocated it could help my case. I'm writing programs for the local public access station. Where any whack-job with 100 bucks gets his own show? God, does it suck. (gives him a business card) Can you help me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, I'll see what I can do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well I parked illegally. See y'later?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (watching Brian go) 'Forgot to introduce you. (a beat) I have a girlfriend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's great. I -- didn't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She saved my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The station is closed. Milo's car is parked, empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We find him, in an illuminated phone booth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) How's it going down there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been hacking for five night's straight, I'm really making headway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A funky space, posters on the wall, a red Stanford pennant, rubber trees at either end of his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the wall beyond Teddy the word GOOK (in blood red) has been covered over with paint but still bleeds through.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But these, like, White Supremacists trashed my office, last week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're in the neighborhood. They usually hassle Vietnamese grocers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, Teddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm cool. They didn't touch the machine. Or my disks. Probably didn't know what they were. So, you a Moonie yet? (he waits) Milo?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I met this girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? Come on. Is it serious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you tell Alice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! I keep thinking it'll go away. But there's this -- connection. She's been hacking since she was little, she had to move around a lot. Plus I see her every day, we're working on the same program. She's -- beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A beautiful geek? I don't wanna sound paranoid, or like a pig, but what're the chances?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What d'you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I dunno. I guess Larry's got me totally suspicious of that place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does that mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo, geeks don't have two girlfriends. Most don't have one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't plan this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: #20 QUAD - DAY Through a window, we watch Milo traverse the quad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) What'd the girl say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There may be a little less trust after your outburst.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gary turns back inside, where Phil reads Milo's new code.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil is confused by Gary's sincerity; so is Gary.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hasn't affected his work, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing does. Still. I want him to like me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: #20 PARKING LOT - EVENING Desi and another Geek watch in astonishment: Gary walks Milo to his car, his arm circled over Milo's shoulder. He seems to be -- apologizing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & ALICE'S HOUSE - EVENING Milo comes eagerly up the path: can't wait to tell Alice what just happened. He enters -- pulls up short. Alice is waiting for him. She's white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't know how to say it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo is staggered. She moves to him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs onto her, for support.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Teddy was killed last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What're you -- what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was a hate crime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . (SILICON VALLEY) - DAY Establish the funky building, vestiges of police tape on the door, a limo and many cars parked out front.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A mixture of Teddy's relatives and Computer Friends have gathered. In the BG, Teddy's Dad weeps volubly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Teddy's brother, NELSON, shows Milo the workspace: red Stanford pennant, rubber trees on the desk. Milo, in a suit, peers at the painted-over epithet on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nelson shows Milo a San Jose Mercury: mugshots of two skin- headed Aryan Nations Members in their 20's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo unpins a picture of himself & Teddy from a board.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo is stung by this. Alice appears in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo is pinning the picture back up. The pushpin falls to the floor, he kneels to retrieve it. On the floorboards, he sees a thin, shiny plastic filament. He picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But when he looks up, Nelson's gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he heads out with Alice, he unthinkingly stuffs the filament in his suit pocket.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They trashed his hard disk, all his back-ups. Nothing's left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They caught the guys?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's an airtight case. They found the weapon with Teddy's blood on it and their fingerprints. They'd been arrested twice for beating-up Asians. How come they weren't in jail?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He told me about the break-in. He didn't seem to take it that seriously.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You guys don't take anything seriously do you? That's not on a hard drive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nelson? Your mom wants you. It's time to go to scatter the ashes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't know he was working with fiber optics.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We gotta go too, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A raw beautiful bluff. The sea stretches to infinity behind a smaller group of Mourners. A LAY MINISTER intones the Lord's Prayer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo approaches Larry with trepidation. Larry nods, it's okay. They hug each other. They walk slowly back toward the cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They smile. For a moment, they've brought Teddy back to life. Alice comes up from behind, to fetch Milo.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know you lost all his work. Maybe I could come down here and -- LARRY You are naive. Look at your employment contract: you can't work anywhere else in this field for at least few years. (he smiles sadly) Not that I don't miss you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just thought his work should go on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was on the verge of something, too. He was gonna show us the next day. He said "The answer's not in the box, it's in the band." Know what it means?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's only meaningful when you've got 40,000 lines of code to back it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Man, could he write code. Totally elegant. He had his own style.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those really weird, short lines.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take good care of this guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . 20 - DAY Arriving for work, Milo sees Outpost flags at half mast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Milo comes up the hall, Lisa is standing there. We get the feeling she's been waiting for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her, perhaps hearing Teddy's words ("what're the chances?"). He nods, moves on. She watches him head up the hall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Milo types. There is a rapping on the doorframe. Gary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary nods. Spontaneously Milo stands, hugs Gary.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I heard what happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were the flags for Teddy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Had you talked to him much lately?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just once. 'Guess I was worried we didn't have anything to talk about, since work was off-limits. Non- disclosure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Talk about work? Never!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I meant did you find other stuff to -- MILO Oh. Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been coming in early.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It helps. Alice said it would help. To focus on something. (a little guilty) 'Don't know what I'd do without her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & ALICE'S HOUSE - MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT Milo sits on the couch, in dim light. Alice comes in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You okay? (sits by him, holds him) I miss him, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Milo eats alone. Through the window, he sees Lisa inside. She's eating alone, too. Gary comes trotting up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is unclasping a manila envelope; he takes pages out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seeing Gary's code, Milo knits his brow: it must be sort of like -- Teddy's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo's smile freezes. As he stares at Gary, we zoom with a reverse dolly so that the background retreats queasily but Gary remains dominant in frame. For Milo, it feels like the very ground is going out from under him. Gary continues to explain, pointing at lines of code. And Milo pretends to listen. But he can't even make out the words Gary speaks -- he hears only a jumble of echoes. Milo nods mechanically; he wants to scream. Or run. He perceives, amid the echoes, that Gary is standing, smiling, saying "See you later." And he's gone. Milo touches the pages, like some talisman of Teddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It strikes him she always shows up at these moments. He gathers his wits before looking up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Milo?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wow. You must have 20,000 lines of code there...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . But they're real short lines. 'Just came out that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Been thinking about the push mechanism in the handler. And it came over me: it's in the wrong place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (an uncertain smile) The wrong place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The answer's not in the box. It's in the band.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Milo? You okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gotta go home. 'Think I ate something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pulling out of the lot, Milo seizes the car phone. He hits HOME on the speed-dial. Gets a busy signal. Rings off. He's about to press re-dial when he sees the Outpost logo branded on the receiver. He throws it down like it's contaminated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & ALICE'S HOUSE - DAY Middle-of-the-day sounds: chirping birds, school children. Milo pulls to the curb at a bad angle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ./FRONT DOOR/FOYER - DAY He fumbles with his keys. When he gets inside:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves into the bedroom. He sees her through the window, painting in the studio.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Alice? Alice!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He stands outside the studio. Waits for her to look up. She does. She smiles. Then she sees something's wrong. He waits for her to come out here, where it's safe to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He paces, agitated. She watches him. She's skeptical, but doesn't want to appear unsympathetic.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you saying you think they had something to do with his death? Nelson said it was an airtight case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what I'm saying. Maybe -- maybe they hired those guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't see Outpost putting its reputation in the hands of people like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know! I just know it was Teddy's code. All these ideas flying in from everywhere. You know how he says "Any kid working in his garage can put us out of business?" It's like they know what every kid's doing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They hack into people's programs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody does work like this on-line. It's in your PC, or in a mainframe. Self-contained. They'd have to be, like, watching people. Physically. (he freezes) Oh Jesus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Milo's at the closet, rummaging among the clothes hanging there. Alice comes up behind him. He finds his suit jacket. He digs in one pocket, then another. He finds the fiber optic strand (from Teddy's floor). Shows it to her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (almost silently) It's a camera.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They've trooped back outside. She's worried she's indulging his paranoia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He knows what she's saying: he's unqualified for this, a space-cadet. She tries to hold him. But he wriggles away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He paces, he thinks. She watches him, worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She can't lie. She shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It isn't a broadcast studio. It's -- a surveillance post or something. That's why they have the dishes on top.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're scaring me. I think we should just go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go where? You can't get away from people like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Like this?" It's Gary you're talking about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (it really hurts) You think I don't know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo. Why would he -- MILO How should I know? "Solving a problem," I guess. Or needing to control everything. I don't know. (can't think about it) I've gotta get in there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even if all this were true. There're 20 other buildings. All of them filled with computers and -- MILO It's the only one with dishes on the roof. The studio's a front. That's why they keep postponing its opening. (muttered, obsessive) ...gotta get in there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo, you told me those DOJ Agents are all over the place. How could they hope to hide a surveillance post? (as he mulls this) And how can you get in there, anyway? With the cameras and the swipe cards -- MILO I can't just walk away!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't just walk in, either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They stop the construction work at six or seven. The parking lot's mostly clear by two or three in the morning. Even the early Geeks don't get there before five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it two? Or is it three? Have you ever really noticed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! I can't just keep my head in the sand. That's how I got into this mess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know how to get in there. But you've gotta help me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scared, reluctant) ...Whaddo I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you believe me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just tell me what to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Standing at his window, Milo can see #21. Workers in Hardhats come out of it, carrying lunchboxes. Milo holds a small writing pad. He notes the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alice parks in front of a drugstore. As she gets out of the car, she looks around uneasily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUE MONTAGE) Alice is at the counter, buying a wind-up alarm clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONT. MONTAGE) Milo watches a car pull out of the parking lot, leaving only one or two others. He writes down the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUE MONTAGE) Alice is at the counter, among children and mothers, purchasing a chemistry set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He watches a SECURITY GUARD (DELBERT) go into #21 on his rounds, notes the time: 3:45 AM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & ALICE'S - STUDIO - NIGHT (CONTINUE MONTAGE) Alice, wearing dishwashing gloves, ties the alarm clock to a small Tupperware container with copper wire. Milo (wearing latex gloves) is at the sink, mixing chemicals from the toy chemistry set. Alice approaches with the container affixed to the clock. As she holds it out Milo pours the mixture into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: we hear ticking. The screen lightens to show:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SUPPLY CLOSET (BUILDING 20) Milo's alarm clock is set for 11:00. It sits amid mops and cleaning products.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 20 HALLWAY - DAY Milo stands in the open door of a refrigerator, as if searching for a soda. He's looking up the hall, waiting for someone. He consults his watch. 10:53.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here comes a GUARD; he nods to Milo as he passes. The Guard opens a door with his card. Milo rushes through the door on the Guard's swipe -- "tailgating."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo cops an attitude. He's not completely convincing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, you gotta use your own -- (noticing) Where's your ID?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know who I am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's my job, I gotta -- MILO (he's getting better) The kind of stock options I'm sitting on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bob Shrot, the ex-cop in charge of physical security, looks up as the Guard escorts Milo into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SUPPLY CLOSET - CONTINUOUS The bomb explodes. The blast is tiny but loud (glass cleaning bottles ring; plastic bottles moan).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo sits, watches Shrot encode a new card for him, finding his info on a terminal. On a monitor behind Shrot, Milo sees Programmers being ushered out of the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANOTHER GUARD rushes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shrot comes to his feet, grabs a holster (with gun) off a shelf. Milo, looking flummoxed, stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo sits. Shrot goes out with the Guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo moves quickly to the wall, reads a chart with the Guards' Schedule, runs his finger down it til he finds the name of the Guard on the 3 AM shift: DELBERT, KEN.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Every geek has to try this once to show me how smart he is --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was an explosion in a Y-sector closet, we're evacuating the whole sector.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Un-nh, can't wander around without ID now. Just park your ass in that chair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Whole place reeks of fuckin' ammonia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Guards open closet doors, shine their flashlights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo has moved to Shrot's seat. He's encoding a fresh card with Ken Delbert's information.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Panning off the civil defense sign we find Shrot standing at a closet, examining a piece of the alarm clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo is at work, bringing up schematic screens, diagnosing the system with his unique concentration. Panning to the window, we see the evacuated Programmers enjoying themselves on the lawn. It's a rare, exciting event: they jump around, miming explosions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shrot and the Guard collect pieces of the bomb out of the debris, puts them in a tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo brings up the screen that controls the #21 cameras. On the monitors, he sees nothing very interesting: a hallway, a room under construction... He pulls down a menu. RECORDING is highlighted. He clicks PLAYBACK. The image hardly changes, but a Guard wanders through. He types, the tape rewinds (the Guard moves backwards). He finds a neutral spot (showing an empty hallway), stops the tape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary, Randy & Phil approach Shrot; Gary stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary explodes, with incredulity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary strides off. Shrot feels unfairly maligned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Randy and Phil head up the hall. Shrot watches them. Even if his "intellectual superiors" are convinced of Milo's innocence, he isn't. He walks swiftly back toward his office. Then he runs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not much. Glorified cherry bomb. Right by the civil defense sign? Some geek's idea of irony. I been saying we need a camera in this hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing in this hall. Someone's pulling your chain, as usual.
dialogue.name: dialogue
