dialogue.raw_text: (thinking aloud) Unless it's a diversion. Milo's in my office. He was tailgating, so I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo? Try to have a clue. Try to think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That kid's the great white hope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could get it out of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not listening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: DOWNLOADING PLAYBACK STREAM TO RECORD CYCLE WILL CAUSE BIT OVERLOAD

direction.raw_text: Milo reads a warning message. DOWNLOADING PLAYBACK STREAM TO RECORD CYCLE WILL CAUSE BIT OVERLOAD. DO YOU WISH TO PROCEED? Y/N. He types Y. The glitch freezes the tape (we see it lock into place): it shows the empty hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've let the Programmers back in. They head up the hall as Shrot heads down it. He pushes past them gruffly. He knows he's enhancing his Neanderthal image (they make cracks) but he's more interested in obeying his instinct.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo immobilizes another camera in #21... and another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shrot rounds the corner. His office is in view, now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo, at the keyboard, closes up windows, one by one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shrot is back, he has only to round the corner to see Milo. We assume his POV as he does so: Milo sits in the chair where Shrot left him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Everything okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pan off the clock (3:20 AM) to find Milo at his desk, looking at the clock with a certain dread. It's time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 20 QUAD - NIGHT Milo walks the path between the two buildings, fiddling nervously with the dummied swipe card. Hearing footfalls behind him, he whirls: it's a Geek loping to his car. He smiles. Milo smiles: waits, walks on. Nearing #21, Milo looks around, making sure no one else is around. His POV (panning): A Programmer works late, visible through a lighted window in #20... The dog sculpture with cocked ears sits atop the Day Care, its quizzical expression seeming to wonder what Milo is up to... The Geek he just saw racing by on foot now pulls out of the parking lot in his James Bond BMW... Milo arrives at the entrance. Heart pounding, he brings the card to the slot. Will he trigger that awful alarm? He slides the card, the door clicks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 21 - LOBBY - CONTINUOUS He enters: concrete floor, unpainted walls, construction lights. At the inner door he looks up at the camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: that shows us where Milo stands, minus Milo. Widen:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: packs up his stuff, getting ready to go home. The new guard, KEN DELBERT enters.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How's it goin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking out his cup) Big night. Switched from tea to coffee. Brought new meaning to my work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? Maybe I'll start my rounds with #21 tonight.

dialogue.raw_text: You are a wild man.

direction.raw_text: . 21 - INNER HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS Milo moves up a hall with unpainted walls, bare floors, unconnected wires. The only illumination is from construction lights on the concrete floor. Opening doors, he sees: Bare rooms. Wall plates ready to receive electrical equipment, bundles of wire hanging out. In other words: the building is as advertised, so far.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delbert comes out with his flashlight, heads across the clean- swept path that leads to #21.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 21 - HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS Milo nears a set of double-doors at the end of the hall. He hears a low ominous hum from within. Convinced he's found something, he quickens his pace. He's about to swipe his card when a beam of light bounces along the wall. He presses himself into an alcove. Through a chink in the unfinished wall he sees: Delbert come in the front door. His rounds consist of shining his torch up at the cameras, making sure the red lights are on. He walks right past Milo (who doesn't breath). Delbert swipes open the double doors, leans in: the humming gets louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : pressing himself into the alcove. Delbert turns around, heads back down the hall... exits the building. Milo waits a beat before heading to the end of the hall. Using the card, he enters
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A studio-to-be, architectural touches like soffits framed in but not plaster-boarded. The portentous hum comes from around a corner. He approaches, convinced the answer lies here. Clearing the wall he sees: A squat emergency generator sitting on the floor, powering construction lights. Something you'd buy at Sears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . #21 ENTRANCE/A MOMENT LATER - (BINOCULAR SHOT) Through infra-red binoculars we see Milo come out, looking left and right, to make sure he hasn't been observed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well. Now he knows: nothin' in there.

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe he'll get back to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Speaking of which...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: CONTINUOUS From a high angle, we track Milo, as he walks along the path to a bench. The camera passes briefly behind a dark object in the foreground (dog sculpture) as we track him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - TIGHTER - CONTINUOUS Milo sags onto the bench. He stares out, perplexed, suffering. Then he knits his brow. He seems to be studying -- the ground. Or rather the shadow stretched out in front of him: the looming silhouette of the dog atop the Day Care. He stands up, turns around. REVERSE ON: The whimsical canine. Push toward it's ears cocked to the sky... Then toward a single ear, framed by fur-brown concrete, but with a smooth, concave inner surface of enamelled metal: satellite dish.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (muttering) ...in a tree...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: At the entrance, Milo applies the swipe-card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps in on colorful carpeting, amid balls & tricycles. Kid's artwork hangs on the wall. He moves through this room, into the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: screens glow. They hang suspended over a wide, ringed table, a chair at each keyboard. Indeed, Gary has spared no expense for the toddlers: they're flat, sleek, digital screens. At the moment, they show colorful, childish contour drawings that say WHERE I WANNA WORK (e.g.: a spaceship). There are a dozen more screens on tables at the perimeter of the room showing screensavers (eg: angelfish swimming). Milo moves slowly around the table, studying the screens. Not surprisingly, most of the WHERE I WANNA WORK drawings are of desks or tables with computers. Tracking just ahead of Milo, we get to a screen that shows a workstation with a red pennant on the wall, a rubber plant at each end of a desk. Even in contour form it's -- familiar. Milo passes it. And comes back to it. Staring at it, he sits. He begins typing. [The drawing still occupies the screen, but in a window he's brought up at the bottom, there is dense, DOS-looking code.] He types furiously -- numbers, symbols, backslashes. Whatever he's trying to do is a challenge even to him. He deletes lines, begins anew, his frustration evident. As he works through the layers of code, the pixels on the screen start to fill in. The contour lines slowly dissolve into a live broadcast image of Teddy's workstation in Sunnyvale (eerily empty, now). When all the pixels have fallen into place, Milo hears CLICK CLICK CLICK CLICK CLICK from every direction, as all the screens in the room fill in with live broadcast images. All of them show variations on a theme: A workstation seen by a camera over-the-shoulder of a programmer (if he were present). The stations are of various shapes and sizes, but in each case we have an unobstructed view of screen & keyboard. At this hour, few programmers are present. One guy has fallen asleep, his head on a desk. A Japanese Geek is hard at work: it's day there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil and Randy work at the coffee table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you download Corey? In San Jose?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn. 'Have to go back over there. (he stands, stretches) Be so much easier if we could walk in the front door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't look anything like a three- year-old.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: TARGET SCHOOLS, PD UPLOADS, RX UPLOADS

direction.raw_text: Milo works the keyboard. Again, the code gets dense and obscure as he goes deeper. He succeeds in calling-up a graphical interface. Among the menus he can choose from are: TARGET SCHOOLS, PD UPLOADS, RX UPLOADS. He clicks Target Schools, a menu shoots down (Berkeley, Cal Tech, etc.). He clicks Stanford, then Chin, Teddy. Two windows open. In one, there is a video stream of Teddy winning an award in the Gate's Bldg. In the other, uploaded police video stenciled SUNNYVALE PD) of the White Supremacists whose mug- shots we saw in the San Jose Mercury; they're being interrogated. In the first window, Teddy's image dissolves into a handheld crime-scene video (marked SV-PD) of a ransacked grocery store. "DIE GOOK!" is painted on a wall. Milo looks confused: some "narrative" is unfolding, but it remains obscure without audio. He types some more. In the bottom window, he brings up convoluted text regarding the audio. About the only phrases we can understand are: "Audio Block ON" and "Hardware Requirement: Magnetic Filter Type PBX-R17." His eyes cast about the room for some suitable hardware substitute. He digs in his shirt pocket. He takes out his swipe card, studies it. He casts about some more, till he sees some kids' safety scissors in a jar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Randy whistles as he heads up the hall. Arriving at the door with the Civil Defense sticker, he swipes his card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On-screen, long-lens footage shows a low building; the Aryan Nations suspects come out of it. A still photo appears in the 2nd window: a steel hasp. Milo's eyes are narrowed: what am I seeing? Meantime, he is reaching under the table where he has removed a plate from the mainframe terminal, exposing hardware within. He has trimmed the swipe card to size and is wedging its magnetic strip into a metal slot. He wiggles the card. We hear an eerie fibrillation, which flattens into the voice of a serene, eminently sane female:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crime-scene video streams in now stenciled FBI by the time/date). A handheld camera pans a blood-spattered wall then shows a mutilated Asian murder victim. (All of this footage is made even eerier by the jerky glitches always present in streaming video, and its sinister graininess.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo pales as he realizes he is watching a primer on how racial killings are done. He hears a creaking noise behind him, and whirls. It's the classroom hamster, on his wheel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: run this methamphetamine lab known to Federal Authorities, per ND 47, from which we removed the implement, fingerprints intact.

direction.raw_text: Milo has tapped into his own file: footage of him lecturing at Stanford (as an RA), pointing to a whiteboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The audio crackles and drops out again. Milo's eyes narrow: he sees video of Alice, sitting on a folding chair, speaking to someone. She has a harder look, pulls on a Marlboro. What's he seeing? He wiggles the jerry-rigged hardware almost urgently, till the narration crackles back on:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hears her voice under the Narration, answering an unseen Interrogator (sounds like Phil). It's a job interview. Milo subtly, unconsciously shakes his head, as if to deny what his eyes see. The narration begins to fibrillate, again:

direction.raw_text: The audio drops out as Milo sees uploaded medical files and ER photos of himself marked STANFORD MEDICAL CENTER: he's waxen, bloated, gasping for breath. With a certain dread, Milo jams the card in deeper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo is devastated, disbelieving. Now he sees real-time ER footage: an Allergy Victim, bloated, twitching, gasping, dying...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The audio crackles out. But Milo doesn't have the heart to bring it back: he can fill in the rest.

dialogue.raw_text: complete immersion in code-writing renders him both unobservant and suggestible [click]. On two occasions he went truant from classes to attend Comix Conventions.

Milo arches it, avoids a knee by mere millimeters.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : knits his brow as his screen flickers. He keeps typing, but starts to lower his head: he's going to look under the table.

direction.raw_text: : winces as he presses the tower upward with his heels, while trying to maintain his balance...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : lowering his head, keeps his eyes on the screen, hits keys. Just as he is about to clear the level of the table -- the screen re-illumines. He comes back up.

direction.raw_text: Milo traces Randy's steps. He sees the door with the Civil Defense sticker, intuits how Randy got here, i.e, how one moves, unobserved, between the Day Care and #20. He sags against the wall. Wondering what to do, now.

Move in on the photo, till we see the number on Barton's Notre Dame football jersey: ND 47. Milo's smile fades. It takes a moment before he even hears Barton behind him.

direction.raw_text: She sits by him, touches her hand to his face tenderly. He closes his eyes for a moment, steels himself to her touch. Then he forces himself to cup his hand over hers. But he can't stand it. He gets up, looks out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't see her smile: is that all. Assuming an appropriately concerned expression, she moves toward him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns him around, kisses him. Her eyes are closed. His remain open. He's looking at her. Trying to comprehend the treachery. She touches him, breathes heavily. She wants more than kisses: to prove to herself how wrong Phil was, her professional pride insulted. Or perhaps it's more personal than that, especially with Lisa as a potential rival.

direction.raw_text: But she doesn't stop. She moans as she presses herself to him: wants proof of his devotion.

direction.raw_text: They're in a bandshell. The rain falls heavily, drips off the eaves. She holds the filament from Teddy's workspace.

direction.raw_text: She's peering at him. He reads her mind.

direction.raw_text: She draws her hands to her face as the facade cracks. She weeps silently. He moves to her, carefully, slowly, seeing her fear, her trauma. He touches her shoulders. She tenses, tries to back away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he holds on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly, he wraps his arms around her. She remains tense for a moment, then yields, pressing her face into his shoulder. The rain drums on the bandshell. After a moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She clings to him tightly, now, the wall of her mistrust breached after all the years of pain, secrecy, shame. A wide shot: they hold each other, alone in the storm.

dialogue.raw_text: It's easy to know who the smart geeks are, the schools tell 'em. They upload medical files, school records, pharmacy files. They'd be happy just to steal code forever. But when a program gets close to fruition. Like Teddy. He was almost there.

dialogue.raw_text: But why would they --?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know. There is no second place. And what's the risk? The killings're undetectable, they're hand-tailored, they make "sense." I mean, they're in the information business. They have scenarios for all of us, too. In case we find out too much.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not one of them. Not trying to "suss you out."

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'll have to use one over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's like eight women waiting in line. They take forever. (winces: painful bladder) Please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He stands there a moment, breathes deeply. He cracks open the door. The Houseman is turning away another Guest; Milo makes his move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Looking over his shoulder, Milo hurries to a door at the far end of the room, silently cursing the Mondrian that inevitably appears. The Houseman looks over his shoulder, sees the closed bathroom door, assumes Milo's still inside.

direction.raw_text: Gary chats with his guests. Alice looks up at the digital art, now a Bosch again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo walks fast. As he passes from one room to next, he sees a Mondrian: he's been in this room. All the austere, tastefully decorated rooms are blending together. He stands in the center of the room making quarter turns. Through each of four (open) doorways he sees a perfectly- appointed "den," the ultimate expression of bland, rich, professionally-decorated taste. He's lost. He starts into one room -- backs up -- goes into another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Houseman looks over his shoulder again. He sees the Mondrian and, in the room beyond that, another Mondrian. He moves to the bathroom door, knocks on it. Opens it. He pulls a sleek walkie-talkie from his jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo, still lost, is getting frantic. He doubles back, cuts toward another wing of the house. Through an open doorway he sees: A young, chillingly calm NANNY, watching him. The Baby fusses in her arms. Milo smiles, keeps moving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Second Houseman follows the trail of Mondrians. He sees Mondrians in two different directions. He hesitates, picks a direction, keeps moving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first Houseman moves through the Guests, toward Gary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo has finally made it. Sitting at Gary's work station, he slips a CD-ROM into the PC. It floods with text. The music echoes from far off. The entire wall behind him is filled with a Mondrian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Linder chats, the first Houseman sidles up to Gary, whispers in his ear. We see Gary smile, excuse himself. He and Alice share a look as he moves off. We go with Gary. His smiles fades instantly. He pushes through Guests, who thank him for hosting such a brilliant "do;" he hardly hears them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo writes frantically on his tiny pad, copying from the PC screen:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Degrees 03 Minutes 58 Seconds East
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Degrees 55 Minutes 14 Seconds South
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - 426 MILES He flips the page, begins entering the fixes for the next satellite. Thinking he's heard something, he looks up. Nobody's there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Second Houseman turns in several directions, confused by the trail of Mondrians. Passing into the next room, he runs into a Third Houseman, also confused. Each follows a different Mondrian, in a different room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unlike the Housemen, Gary doesn't follow the paintings. He moves swiftly, seems to know where Milo is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Milo still working...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Alice looks up at the digital painting: still a Bosch. Her face sets grimly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo clicks, closing the window. Concentrating, he doesn't see what we see on the wall behind him: the Mondrian drains away... And the wall fills up with the hellish Bosch triptych. After a moment, Milo senses something. Gary stands in the doorway. Watching him. Milo doesn't breathe. Gary crosses the room, eyes locked with Milo's. Gary comes behind Milo. He reads the screen. It's filled with text, whatever Milo loaded in when he sat down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary stares at Milo. He looks skeptical. The party music floats in from afar as the moment stretches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This hangs there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Second Houseman sticks his head in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks over. Milo looks over. Among the framed commendations, awards, degrees we see Milo's childhood program, written on Outpost 1.0. Gary has had it framed. Milo absorbs it. Even now, he feels something for Gary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo smiles almost tenderly. He doesn't know if Gary buys it. Perhaps if he could see Gary's eyes. But they're obscured by Bosch's writhing bodies, reflected on his eyeglasses. Gary moves away from Milo, he stands over the table with the art books, vaguely looks through one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo wonders: does he know? He picks his words carefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gary puts down the book. Something in his tone draws Milo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this a confession? A plea for understanding? Or just a pep-talk to keep Milo focused on Skywire?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reading the screen) "Dear Lisa. I've enjoyed working with you. I'd be lying if I didn't say I find you attractive. But in my heart I know that Alice..." (he looks up) You left my party to send E-mail?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could've handwritten it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's right. You're "clueless."

dialogue.raw_text: Gary, I'm sorry if I was rude --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everything OK, Mr. Boyd?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No problem. (when he's gone) Is there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gary, I -- GARY You see what's hanging on the wall?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope you know what you mean to me. Not just because of what you're doing. Because of who you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do know, Gary. I feel the same way. I thought I was coming here for a job. But it's meant a lot more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When will you have a Beta version?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm pretty close. But when I wrote the last contact switches, it wiped out a piece of the content filer. You know what it's like, writing software.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do know. You focus on the big problem. But somewhere down the chain, something breaks down. Something gets destroyed. At first it's upsetting. You feel you've lost control.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you have to remind yourself: it's just the process. Something's always lost along the way to anything worthwhile. Some little bug, some glitch. 'Can't get bogged down in that, you're doing something other people could never do. They lack the imagination, the brain, the nerve. Let them fret about every unforeseen consequence. You have to solve the problem. That's who you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the car, Milo and Alice pull away from the lights and limos in icy silence. Several beats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her. She stares ahead, out the windshield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd better have his story straight with Gary and Alice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or is she faking it? Has he lost the trust of all of them? He's afraid, now.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you gonna tell me where you went?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I went to see the Skywire model in Gary's office. You know. Just to hold it again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you having an affair, Milo?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. No. I sent an E-mail to somebody, just now. To tell her how I feel about you. (looks at her) You know I'm clueless, without you. You know I -- ALICE (fighting tears) Just shut up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We hear the children's shouts OS. Short, with a fingerprint kit, is dusting the keyboards. Len stands over him.

dialogue.raw_text: Get the backslash, the colon, keys kids don't use but geeks do. (looking around, perplexed) What would Milo want in here, anyway?

dialogue.raw_text: They know. 'Just they don't trust me with it. So we'll get the evidence, first, ask questions later.

direction.raw_text: By the balustrade, in the dimness, Milo stands with Lisa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him, worried, then takes a disk out of her backpack.

direction.raw_text: He takes it. They kiss. She watches him go, worried.

dialogue.raw_text: Does he know you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He suspects I know something. I think he was sort of -- explaining himself to me, in case I do. (he breathes) We have to go in tonight. I'm two hours from a Beta version. (knows she won't like it) But I've gotta go home for an hour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She called to apologize. I said I was pulling an all-nighter. She said then come home just to say Hi. Which I always do when we fight, it's suspicious if I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please don't go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At this point the worst thing I could do is anything out of the ordinary.

dialogue.raw_text: Here's the interface.

direction.raw_text: As Milo comes up the path, he sees Alice in the kitchen. He opens the front door, steps in. She comes from the kitchen in an apron, wiping her hands. The apron is spattered, her hair is askew.

direction.raw_text: He smiles to hide his terror. Is she killing him now? Or just testing his reaction? Or is it a sincere overture?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When she turns away, we see the fear on his face.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a mess! I got this Hunan cookbook, since we're always afraid for you to eat in Chinese restaurants. I've been mincing things into teeny-tiny pieces all afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at me! I'm gonna change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Alice pulls into a dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Milo, at the stove, sniffs at the food that simmers in a wok. He grabs a a spoon, examines it; but it's minced too fine to discern one ingredient from another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alice pulls her hair back with a ribbon...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo churns the garbage in the wastebasket, reads the label on a jar, the label on a can...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alice applies blush-on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo goes through the spice cabinet...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milo paces. He stops when she comes from the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Either she's the most cold-blooded woman in the world, or... He takes her in his arms, kisses her long and hard -- as if his life depended on it. When he releases her, she pretends to swoon. She backs toward the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (he smiles) You look beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? Give me a goodbye kiss.

dialogue.raw_text: ...What?

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUOUS Milo's fingers drum the table top...

direction.raw_text: - MOVING - CONTINUOUS (ALICE'S POV) We hold the dish out in front of us. The food shines in the light, a poisonous yellow gleam. We move from kitchen to dining room, slowly, deliberately... Milo comes into view beyond the dish, wearing a forced smile. We come all the way to the table with the dish, where Alice sets it down. She sits. Milo, still vamping, pours wine. He picks up his fork. Stares at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His mind churns furiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When she's gone, he flips his left arm over and drags the tines of his fork against it, making score-marks, like those used by allergists to test for sensitivity. He dabs the sauce onto the tracks, wipes it clean. He stares at it.

dialogue.raw_text: Milo?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milo?

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, right. Hold on.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But here's Alice. She slips into her seat.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles, picks up her glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They toast. She sips her wine. He sips his. He wants desperately to glance at his inner arm once more. But she's watching him, waiting for him to eat. He picks up the chopsticks, gathers up a tiny bite. She watches keenly. He brings the food to his mouth, passes it between his lips, swallows. He closes his eyes, ostensibly to savor the food, in fact bracing for a paroxysm. She watches him expectantly -- either for his verdict on the food, or for the first fatal spasm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She grins. She takes a bite. The moment she looks away, he turns over his arm to get a look, face full of fear. The tracks are still flat, there's no redness. He shovels a large bite into his mouth, ecstatic to be alive. Then another bite, greedy with life.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (under his breath) One more minute...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here we go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...wanna savor this.

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Wait. A toast.

dialogue.raw_text: To the artist.

In a second window, other fingerprints flash by: thousands of prints lifted off keyboards in the Day Care. Shrot waits for a match to click in.

direction.raw_text: Milo scrolls his Skywire code, concentrating intensely. Till he feels some stickiness on his thumb and forefinger. He rubs them together, peers at his keys. Dolly-zoom in on a trace of fingerprint powder. Fear seizes Milo. He ejects his the Skywire CD -- it is a bright silver color, with a Skywire logo on it -- slips it in an equally distinct silver (CD) jewel-case.

direction.raw_text: Each shows the standard Outpost desktop: Outpost logo, fonts, colors. [This is the all-purpose interface Lisa created for to Milo.] A window at the top shows a succession of Obituaries with photos Lisa has downloaded from newspapers: "Programmer Dies in Highway Crash;" "Programmer Among Cult Suicides;" "Programmer Victim of Racial Killing," etc.) The obituaries -- eight of them -- fade up and down in a continuous cycle. Meantime: Lower on the screen, the material from the day-care data tower appears, following the same succession we saw when Milo brought up Teddy's data, i.e., footage of a young Programmer at college, surveillance footage of him typing away (from behind), medical records that describe his vulnerability or a crime primer that describes his scenario. Between the obits and the primers, cause and effect is (eventually) established. The crowning note is the audio, Gary in VOICE OVER, gleaned (by Lisa) from the audio version of his own book:

direction.raw_text: . The cuts accelerate. In a NETWORK CONTROL ROOM, Technicians flip switches, trying to bring back scheduled programming. At the NIKKEI, the Brokers are transfixed by what comes over the Big Board. In a VEGAS CASINO Gamblers sip their drinks as they watch it on closed-circuit horserace monitors. On a STREET CORNER, a Crack Dealer watches on his beeper. At a STADIUM, the Stones play but (tilting up) the Diamond Vision behind them plays Milo's broadcast. In an ELECTRONICS STORE, a wall of TV's -- 200 of them -- plays grisly primer footage for Shoppers. A guy takes a shiny wrapped copy of Outpost '98 from his basket, returns it to the shelf... In the Day Care Computer Room, it plays on all the monitors as Randy moves through the room with a big buzzing electro-magnetic hoop, which he runs over each tower, wiping out data. Through all the cuts, we hear Gary's narration:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's why we work so hard to invent or acquire great new applications. Consumers don't care where new ideas come from, just so long as they're offered at competitive prices.
